name: Deep-Fried Pickles
headline: Deep-Fried Pickles
keywords: Vegetarian,Dutch Oven,Cast Iron Skillet,American,Pickle Recipes,Cornmeal,Grain Recipes,Cucumber,Buttermilk,Dairy Recipes,Appetizer,Deep-Frying,Gluten Free
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon kosher salt, plus more, if desired

recipeInstructions.text: Place enough peanut oil in a 4 to 5-quart cast iron Dutch oven to come halfway up the side of the pot. Place over medium-high heat and bring to 390 to 400 degrees F.
Remove the pickles from their brine and cut lengthwise into quarters, like spears. Lay the spears on a sheet pan lined with paper towels and pat them dry.

Place the buttermilk in 1 shallow dish and mix together the cornmeal and salt in a separate dish. Dip each pickle, 1 at a time, first into the buttermilk, then into the cornmeal and then repeat. Carefully place each spear into the hot oil and cook until golden brown, approximately 2 minutes. You can fry 3 to 4 pickles in the pot at a time. Adjust the heat, if necessary, in order to maintain a constant temperature of 390 to 400 degrees F. Transfer the pickles to a cooling rack set in a half sheet pan and allow to cool for 5 minutes before eating. Season with additional salt, if desired.

review.reviewBody: just made them they were fast and delicious! i had to make mt own buttermilk though with 1 tablespoon of viniger to 1 cup milk let sit for 5 minutes then use
They were easy and tasted great. However, they were gritty (and I used real cornmeal). They just needed something else. But delicious, and I'd make again! I love fried pickles!

These were very easy and tasted great. You have to start with a good pickle, otherwise there is no point in trying this recipe. We made them with both dill pickles and bread and butter pickles. People liked one or the other based on their preference in the pickle. Look forward to making this recipe again.
Made these for our cooking club and everybody loved them, even our friend who doesn't like pickles!  Better room temperature, not hot.
Very easy, fast and so yummy

For what my info is worth ... Alton's recipe provides a clear and simple recipe. I have used it for pickles (Suggestion: Buy/use pickles of your choice.  If you use a brand of pickles that you don't like...this recipe does not change the basic flavor.  It adds a changed texture....something like fried tomatoes).  I've also used the recipe with green beans, artichoke hearts, seedless cucumbers, etc., etc.  Thanks Alton

great job alton, your my role model!

Elvis would have loved them just like u had said, actually i thought u were going to make a pickle fried peanut butter sandwitch when you mentioned his name, wouldnt be half bad for me to eat.
Finally a fried pickle recipe that the batter sticks too the pickle. so good and you don't feel guilty for eating them. Atleast as guilty!!
These were crispy but relied mainly on the flavor of the pickle for taste.  No "WOW!" factor.  Made up my own recipe using italian bread crumbs and egg wash.  MUCH better!
Easy to set and clean up. Pickles tasted great. Could not keep them on the plate!
Awesome recipe.  Apply the same recipe using dill chips.  Very tasty.
